title: I am filling out request for default setting in my divorce, what happens after I turn these in?
question: I have started a divorce and my husband has not responded to ANYTHING from me or the courts....so i was just given the next set of paperwork and it is called Request For Default Setting....what does that mean and what is the next step?
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Child support,Divorce by default judgment,Divorce and bankruptcy,Child custody,Custody hearings,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Child support order by default judgement,Child support and custody,Lawsuits and disputes,Court basics,Default judgment
answers:
The paperwork you were given will allow you to finalize your divorce without your husband's participation. Since he has chosen not to file a Response, the Court has the authority to enter a final judgment based on what you present at your "prove-up" hearing.

If your case is in Torrance, I assume you will appear before either Slawson or Veasey--both very competent judges. They will ask you some basic questions -- but if you are worried then you can hire a lawyer to appear with you on the day of the court hearing. If you have children, the judge will ask you some questions about your and your husband's income in order to make a child support order. Be prepared to talk about your assets and debts and your preferred custody and visitation schedule. If there are no children and no assets or debts to divide, then the hearing is something you can probably handle yourself. I've included a link below that may be helpful. Good luck to you.

When your husband's default is entered he will be barred from any future participation in the case. The next step for you will be to then submit your desired judgment to the court, so that the case can be complete.

The Court wants you to present your case so they can enter a default Marital Judgment. They have a default hearing and the judge will review your paperwork and ask you questions about your case. That is the way to proceed if the other side does not respond. Have you completed and served your preliminary disclosures? You do have to do that to complete your divorce. Are you at an agency that is assisting you with the paperwork?

Ms. Johns is a lawyer although she is not your lawyer unless you have consulted with her and signed a fee or letter agreement. This post does not constitute legal advice and no attorney client relationship results.
